metadata.title: SELPHI2.0: Data-driven extraction of human kinase-substrate relationships from omics datasets
metadata.description:
In this study, we have created a machine learning-based model to derive a probabilistic kinase-substrate network from omics datasets.  Our methodology displays improved performance compared to other state-of-the-art kinase-substrate prediction methods, and provides predictions for more kinases. Importantly, it better captures new experimentally-identified kinase-substrate relationships. It can therefore allow the improved prioritisation of kinase-substrate pairs for illuminating the dark human cell signalling space. Our model is integrated into a web server, SELPHI2.0, to allow unbiased analysis of phosphoproteomics data, facilitating the design of downstream experiments to uncover mechanisms of signal transduction across conditions and cellular contexts.

The SELPHI2.0 web server is freely available under: https://selphi2.com  and all code for reproducing this project can be found at https://gitlab.ebi.ac.uk/petsalakilab/selphi_2.0 and https://github.com/alussana/selphi2.0-pssms. A Docker image of the web server can be found at: https://gitlab.ebi.ac.uk/petsalakilab/selphi_2.

data.title: SELPHI2.0: Data-driven extraction of human kinase-substrate relationships from omics datasets

metadata.title: Global panorama of phage-host interactions driving antimicrobial resistance gene transfer in livestock manure anaerobic digestion
metadata.description: Antimicrobial resistance poses a global threat to human health, with livestock manure being a major reservoir of antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs). Here, we present a global analysis of 205 metagenomic and 36 meta-transcriptomic datasets from anaerobic digestion (AD) systems treating livestock manure. We reveal that pig manure AD harbors the highest ARG abundance (0.709 ARGs/16S rRNA genes), and the expression of ARGs was found to be at a lower level (abundance/transcription < 0.24). A global viral database of livestock manure AD (GVD_LMAD) comprising 59,316 non-redundant DNA viral operational taxonomic units (vOTUs) and 727 non-redundant RNA vOTUs was established. While lytic phages predominantly reduce ARGs by lysing antimicrobial resistant bacteria, the reproduction and transduction role of viral communities on the transfer of ARGs were also elucidated. We further built the global antiviral defense systems (ADS) catalogue of livestock manure AD (GADSC_LMAD), encompassing 33,996 ADS-related genes, which not only protect antimicrobial resistant bacteria from phage predation but also inhibit the transfer of ARGs. Our findings provide actionable insights for enhancing the reduction of ARGs in livestock manure AD, and underscore the need to integrate phage ecology into AMR mitigation strategies.

data.title: Global panorama of phage-host interactions driving antimicrobial resistance gene transfer in livestock manure anaerobic digestion

metadata.title: Binary relaxor piezoceramic Pb (Mg1/3Nb2/3) O3-PbTiO3 for energy harvesting
metadata.description: Perovskite relaxor-PT piezoelectrics are suitable materials for energy harvesting. Relaxor-PT crystals have electromechanical properties that can replace lead zirconate titanate (PZT). However, the growth of these relaxor PT crystals is tedious and expensive. The important parameter for energy harvesting is the transduction rate (𝑑 × 𝑔) where 𝑑 represents the piezoelectric coefficient and 𝑔 represents the piezoelectric voltage constant. There is always a challenge to obtain a high (𝑑 × 𝑔) value. Lead magnesium niobate Pb (Mg1/3Nb2/3) O3-lead titanate PbTiO3 (PMN-PT) is a binary relaxor-PT ceramic and the morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) of (1-x) PMN-xPT ceramics occur around x=0.29-0.40 which is not exactly defined. So here we have synthesized 0.71PMN-0.29PT, 0.68PMN-0.32PT, and 0.65PMN-0.35PT compositions by two-step sintering solid-state method. The x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the PMN-PT ceramics exhibit a characteristic perovskite structure and also show that PMN-PT ceramics fall within the region of MPB. Out of the three compositions, the 0.71PMN 0.29PT ceramics show a higher transduction rate (𝑑 × 𝑔). So, this piezoelectric ceramic has the potential to replace costly piezoelectric single crystals in the creation of affordable, high-frequency energy harvesting devices.

journal.title: International Journal of Advances in Applied Sciences (IJAAS)

data.title: Binary relaxor piezoceramic Pb (Mg1/3Nb2/3) O3-PbTiO3 for energy harvesting

metadata.title: Mathematical Model and Experimental Characterization of Vertically Stacked Capacitive Tactile Sensors
metadata.description: Capacitive sensors are widely used in robotics for their compactness, high resolution, high sensitivity, and large dynamic range. In this article, we present a design solution for the manufacturing of capacitive tactile sensors with enhanced dynamic range and sensitivity. Herein, we adopted the approach of exploiting the vertical direction of the sensors by creating stacks of capacitors. The validation of the proposed model is conducted by means of finite element simulations and the effectiveness of stacked capacitors in suboptimal configurations has been experimentally tested by using inkjet printing and spin coating-based fabrication techniques. Results show that these sensors exhibit an enhanced dynamic range and sensitivity with respect to common single capacitors, for a given sensors area budget. Sensitivity increases of 235% passing from one-stack to two-stack capacitors (from 5.75 to 19.3 fF/kPa) and a growth of 23% from two-stack to three-stack capacitors (from 19.3 to 23.7 fF/kPa). These results suggest that the proposed methodology could be adopted for designing tactile sensors with higher spatial resolution and higher transduction sensitivity and dynamic range, in the perspective of an integration over large areas.

creators.name: Frascio, Mattia
creators.affiliation: Università degli Studi di Genova Scuola Politecnica

data.title: Mathematical Model and Experimental Characterization of Vertically Stacked Capacitive Tactile Sensors

metadata.title: Effects of capecitabine chemotherapy on the expression of CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 lncRNAs in patients with colorectal cancer and the HCT-116 colorectal cancer cell line
metadata.description:
Background: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third leading cause of cancer-related deaths. Capecitabine is a key chemotherapy drug for colorectal cancer (CRC). Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) play a role in the pathogenic pathways associated with colorectal cancer. This investigation compared the expression patterns of CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 in CRC patients before and after chemotherapy, as well as in healthy individuals. The effects of capecitabine on cell viability, apoptosis, cell cycle, and the expressions of CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 were examined using HCT-116 cells.

Methods: CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 expressions were assessed using qRT-PCR on patients' and healthy tissues. Furthermore, the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis was used to evaluate the prognostic and diagnostic value of CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 in CRC. The MTT test was used to assess capecitabine's cytotoxicity on the HCT-116 CRC cell line. Annexin-V/PI staining was used to examine apoptosis and cell cycle progression by flow cytometry. Gene expression differences between before and after capecitabine treatments were examined by qRT-PCR.

Results: Results showed that patients with colorectal cancer had lower levels of CASC18 but higher levels of CASC19 and CASC20 expression than the healthy group. Moreover, patients treated with capecitabine showed an increased CASC18 expression, while non-significant changes were observed in the expression of CASC19 and CASC20. The clinical factors were not associated with the expression of lncRNAs CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20. Furthermore, results indicated that CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 are poor biomarkers for diagnosis of CRC. MTT analysis revealed a dose- and time-dependent cytotoxic effect for capecitabine on the HCT-116 cells. Capecitabine treatment led to the accumulation of the HCT-116 cells in the Sub-G1 phase, suggesting an apoptotic solid impact on the cells. Moreover, HCT-116 cells were arrested in the G2/M phases by capecitabine. Capecitabine also upregulated CASC18 expression in the HCT-116 cell line.

Conclusion: These results support the anticancer and cytotoxic effects of capecitabine and highlight its ability to increase CASC18 expression. Additionally, the findings indicate that CASC18, CASC19, and CASC20 are poor biomarkers for colorectal cancer (CRC) diagnosis.

metadata.title: Therapy of asthma and Hypersensitivity Responses
metadata.description:
Abstract

An improper reaction against harmless environmental proteins causes allergies. All around the world, allergic disorders have become epidemics. The pathophysiology of allergic hypersensitivity reactions is significantly influenced by allergen-specific T helper (Th) cells. Knowing the cellular and soluble mediators that contribute to allergic inflammatory responses is crucial for identifying new targets that can be targeted by biological and small-molecule therapies, as well as for comprehending the mechanisms underlying existing treatments. Because of advancements in systemic and mucosal allergen-specific immunotherapy, the discovery of important cytokines and their receptors that promote T-helper-2-cell polarization, a better comprehension of the signaling pathways involved in cell activation and mediator secretion, leukocyte recruitment pathways, and novel vaccine development strategies, there is now a great deal of hope for combating the allergy epidemic.

 

 

 

 

 

1.     Introduction

The type-I allergic airway illness known as asthma is characterized by eosinophilic bronchial inflammation and is mediated by Th2 cells and IgE. The chronic inflammation and subsequent airway remodeling might cause symptoms to linger and lung function to decline in a significant majority of individuals (Bogaert, Tournoy et al. 2009).

Asthma and other allergy illnesses have become much more common in recent decades, impacting an estimated 20% of the population in affluent nations. An abnormal immune response against harmless environmental proteins (antigens) is the cause of allergic disorders. Even though we are all constantly exposed to innocuous antigens, only a small portion of people have negative immune reactions to them. This is because the induction of tolerance is linked to the natural immunological response to allergens. Active immunological responses may be induced and sustained if tolerance is revoked or if tolerance is not induced. It is thought that allergen-specific CD4+ T lymphocytes are essential for the onset of asthma. Patients with allergies often have a high frequency of activated allergen-specific T cells in their peripheral blood. The increased synthesis of interleukin (IL)-4, IL-5, IL-9, and IL-13 (Th2 cytokines) is a characteristic of the allergen-specific CD4+ T cells implicated in the onset of allergic reactivity (Romagnani 2000).

It is clear that more people are suffering from allergy illnesses, particularly in developed nations. There have been several theories put up to account for this rise in prevalence. One major claim is the "hygiene hypothesis," which holds that better public health initiatives, greater hygiene, and the use of vaccinations and medicines have all contributed to a decrease in the prevalence of illnesses that would typically trigger the immune system. In order to prevent allergic reactions to harmless environmental chemicals, these infections would "mature" the immune system (Strachan 1989).

High Th2 cytokine levels are one factor contributing to the clinical manifestations of allergy pathogenesis. The development of allergic and asthmatic inflammatory responses is influenced by environmental factors, including exposure to allergens, infections, and air pollution, even though genetic predisposition is the primary determinant for the development of allergy and asthma (Sampson 2004).

Since "reagin" was first described in 1922 and later identified as IgE in 1966, significant progress has been made in our understanding of the chemical mediators involved, the immunological pathways leading to allergy, and the innate and adaptive immune responses that control its expression. Understanding the structure and intrinsic biology of environmental agents that dictate their allergenicity as well as the function of other environmental elements like pollution and microbes in enhancing or reducing allergen sensitization has also advanced (Eder, Ege et al. 2006).

 Since the majority of allergic diseases manifest clinically at mucosal or epidermal surfaces, a disruption of the physical barrier that these surfaces typically offer as well as changes in innate immunity are acknowledged to play a significant role in allergic reactions. The investigation of the relationships between many susceptibility genes and the environment is exposing novel pathophysiological processes and opening up fresh avenues for allergy treatment and prevention. The time has come to examine the new treatment approaches that are currently emerging from a different angle. This review offers a summary of potential novel therapeutics, with particular attention to some intriguing new molecular and immunological targets as well as vaccine strategies for asthma and allergies.

2.     The series of allergic reaction

The TH2-cell pathway, which is selected for the allergic inflammatory response, is started by professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) absorbing allergens and presenting specific peptides on MHC class II molecules to naive T cells. This leads to a TH2-cell phenotype, where cytokine secretion is mediated by the transcription factor GATA3 (GATA-binding protein 3) (Hammad and Lambrecht 2006). In contrast, T-bet regulates the release of cytokines, such as interferon-γ (IFNγ), in the TH1-cell phenotype that predominates in autoimmune disorders. As professional APCs, dendritic cells (DCs) play a critical part in this sensitization process. Hamida Hammad and Bart Lambrecht address this in this issue. B cells are also crucial for the processing and capture of allergens, particularly when there are trace levels of the allergen present (von Garnier, Wikstrom et al. 2007).

 

 

 

 

Figure.1 Allergic mechanisms. The activation of allergen-specific T helper 2 (TH2) cells and IgE synthesis, also referred to as allergic sensitization, are the primary outcomes of professional antigen-presenting cells' (APCs') first contact to an allergen in susceptible individuals. The early (acute) and late allergic reactions are brought on by the recruitment, activation, and release of mediators of inflammatory cells following subsequent allergen stimulation. Within minutes of coming into touch with an allergen, IgE-sensitized mast cells degranulate in the early allergic reaction, releasing mediators that have already been created as well as those that have been synthesized in sensitized individuals. These include cytokines, histamine, and cysteinyl leukotrienes, which encourage the creation of mucus, smooth muscle contraction, and vascular permeability. The recruitment of inflammatory cells that support the late allergy response—which is marked by an influx of TH2 cells and eosinophils—is guided by chemokines generated by mast cells and other cell types. Eosinophils may be a significant source of pro-inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-3 (IL-3), IL-5, and IL-13. They also release a variety of pro-inflammatory mediators, such as cysteinyl leukotrienes and basic proteins (eosinophil peroxidase, cationic proteins, major basic protein, and eosinophil-derived neurotoxin). Some of the pathogenic characteristics in individuals with chronic forms of atopy, such as smooth-muscle cell activation and epithelial apoptosis, may also be caused by TH1-cell responses, according to new research. The inhibition of TH2-cell responses in humans involving the inhibitory cytokines transforming growth factor-β (TGFβ) and IL-10 is influenced by regulatory T (TReg) cells, another significant component of CD4+ T cells. The neutrophilic inflammatory processes that take place during disease aggravation and tissue remodeling appear to be especially linked to TH17 cells, another recently discovered CD4+ T-cell subset identified based on release of IL-17A and IL-17F. TCR stands for T-cell receptor; TNF for tumor-necrosis factor; IFNγ for interferon-γ; and FceRI for high-affinity receptor for IgE.

3.     Theraputic Treatments

 3.1 Formulated treatments

 According to disease-management recommendations, the cornerstones of asthma treatment today are inhaled corticosteroids and short- and long-acting β2-adrenoceptor agonists (SABAs and LABAs). Non-sedating H1-antihistamines and topical corticosteroids are well-established control treatments for rhinitis, whereas α-adrenoceptor agonists are used to reduce nasal congestion. Therefore, the foundation of care guidelines for the majority of allergic illnesses is a combination of symptom-relieving and control therapy. An excellent illustration of how knowledge of the pathophysiology of the condition has supported current treatment strategies is asthma (Barnes, Chung et al. 1998).

Corticosteroids: By suppressing the expression of cytokines, chemokines, and adhesion molecules37, whose encoding genes are controlled by transcription factors like nuclear factor-κB (NF-κB) and activator protein 1 (AP1), corticosteroids reduce TH2-cell-mediated inflammation in asthmatic airways. Diffusing through the cell membrane, free corticosteroids engage with cytoplasmic glucocorticoid receptors. This causes these receptors to become activated and then go into the nucleus, where a variety of processes, including as gene transactivation and gene transrepression, regulate the transcriptional activity of target genes (Barnes and Adcock 1998). Even when treatment is initiated early in childhood, inhaled corticosteroids have no effect on the disease's natural course, despite their great efficacy in reducing airway inflammation.
When it comes to viral exacerbations and asthmatics who smoke, inhaled corticosteroids are mainly ineffective(Barnes and Adcock 2003).

 

 

 

Figure.2. Anti-inflammatory actions of corticosteroids. When corticosteroids enter a cell, they attach to the cytoplasmic glucocorticoid receptor (GR) and go into the nucleus, where they start the transcription of target genes. There are glucocorticosteroid response elements (GREs) in the promoters of several genes. Annexin-1 (lipocortin-1), secretory leukoprotease inhibitor (SLPI), interleukin-10 (IL-10), and the inhibitor of nuclear factor-κB (IκBα) are examples of anti-inflammatory mediators that are transcriptionally activated when the activated glucocorticoid receptor homodimer binds to a GRE in the promoter region of steroid-sensitive genes. By interacting with large co-activator molecules that have intrinsic histone acetyltransferase (HAT) activity (like cyclic AMP response element binding protein, or CBP) and are activated by proinflammatory transcription factors (like NF-κB and AP1), the glucocorticoid receptor–corticosteroid complex transrepresses the expression of the inflammatory genes that these transcription factors activate. RNA polymerase II and RNA pol II.

β2-adrenoceptor agonists: For the quick alleviation of asthma symptoms, inhaled SABAs like salbutamol and turbutaline are the best bronchodilators on the market right now. Protein kinase A is activated when these agonists bind to the β2-adrenoceptor and the signal-transducing Gs protein stimulates adenylate cyclase to promote the generation of cyclic adenosine 3′5′-monophosphate (cAMP). This improves bronchoconstriction in asthma via phosphorylating myosin light-chain kinase and opening Ca2+-dependent K+ (KCa) channels, which causes smooth-muscle relaxation. For the quick alleviation of asthma symptoms, inhaled SABAs like salbutamol and turbutaline are the best bronchodilators on the market right now (Palmqvist, Persson et al. 1997). Protein kinase A is activated when these agonists bind to the β2-adrenoceptor and the signal-transducing Gs protein stimulates adenylate cyclase to promote the generation of cyclic adenosine 3′5′-monophosphate (cAMP). This improves bronchoconstriction in asthma via phosphorylating myosin light-chain kinase and opening Ca2+-dependent K+ (KCa) channels, which causes smooth-muscle relaxation (Usmani, Ito et al. 2005).

3.2 Specific immunotherapy for allergens

Allergen-specific immunotherapy (SIT) is an immune-modifying treatment that has been suggested for mild bronchial asthma, venom hypersensitivity, allergic rhinitis, and certain medication allergies. Repeated exposure to the allergen or allergens causes SIT to produce blocking IgG4 antibodies and immunological tolerance. Following either natural or experimental exposure to allergens, SIT reduces the recruitment of mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils in the mucosa of the skin, nose, eyes, and bronchi (Figure.4). The level of IgA and IgG4 antibodies specific to allergens rises with SIT, but the level of IgE antibodies specific to allergens falls. Additionally, it stimulates CD4+CD25+FOXP3+ TReg cells that generate large amounts of TGFβ and/or IL-10, two cytokines known to reduce TH2-cell responses specific to allergens (Wu, Bi et al. 2007). A varied and self-tolerant T-cell repertoire, including TReg cells6, is maintained by the pleiotropic actions of TGFβ, while IL-10 inhibits mast-cell, eosinophil, and T-cell responses.

 

 

 

Figure.3. Immunological characteristics and the impact of allergen-specific immunotherapy (SIT). SIT alters humoral and cellular reactions to allergens. After SIT, functional regulatory T (TReg) cells are activated and the ratio of T helper 1 (TH1)-cell cytokines to TH2-cell cytokines increases. B cells, T cells, macrophages, and monocytes all produce more interleukin-10 (IL-10). Increased transforming growth factor-β (TGFβ) production may help TReg-cell activity and immunoglobulin class-switching to IgA, IgG1, and IgG4 when combined with IL-10. These immunoglobulins reduce the amount of allergen capture and presentation that IgE facilitates when it forms a complex with either the low-affinity receptor for IgE (FcεRII, CD23) or the high-affinity receptor for IgE (FcεRI) by competing with IgE for allergen binding. Furthermore, SIT reduces both the quantity of mast cells and their capacity to release mediators. Additionally, fewer neutrophils and eosinophils are drawn to areas where allergens are present.

3.3 IgE as a Therapeutic target

Hannah Gould and Brian Sutton go over the sentinel function of IgE in boosting allergen absorption by DCs and triggering mast cells and basophils for mediator release in this issue. It has been demonstrated that IgG antibodies that target the C3 domain of IgE and prevent IgE from binding to FcεRI (as well as FcεRII, CD23) reduce allergen-induced inflammatory reactions in both humans and mice (Corne, Djukanovic et al. 1997). A non-anaphylactic, humanized IgE-specific IgG1 called omalizumab has been created to treat severe allergic asthma (Figure.4). According to clinical trials conducted on adults, adolescents, and children with poorly controlled IgE-mediated asthma, omalizumab given subcutaneously two to four times a week (in proportion to the patient's body weight and the total amount of IgE in their serum) improves symptom control and enables patients to be treated with lower doses of inhaled corticosteroids. Up to 52 weeks of clinical trials have shown that omalizumab is well tolerated.

The initial dose of omalizumab causes a sharp drop in the amount of circulating free IgE, but it takes up to 16 weeks of treatment before the best clinical results are observed. Treatment for allergic rhino conjunctivitis can also be achieved with omalizumab; however, it must start well in advance of the pollen season. The creation of an active immunization vaccine based on peptides to produce long-lasting, protective, IgE-specific antibodies is of interest. IgE peptide-based vaccinations can cause IgE-specific autoantibodies in sensitized rats (Plewako, Arvidsson et al. 2002).Phase II clinical trials for RP01, a new immunotherapeutic that stimulates the development of IgE-specific antibodies, have recently begun. In addition to lowering circulating IgE levels, lumiliximab, an antibody that targets the low-affinity IgE receptor FcεRII, has successfully completed Phase 1 studies for mild to moderate allergic asthma (Vernersson, Ledin et al. 2002).

 

 

 

 Figure.4. The impact of IgE targeting on allergic reactions. In order to reduce allergic reactions, the monoclonal IgEspecific antibody omalizumab can lower free IgE levels and lessen IgE binding to both high-affinity (FcεRI) and low-affinity (FcεRII) IgE receptors. Omalizumab suppresses the production of FcεRI and prevents IgE from attaching to mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils. In order to stop IgE-dependent allergen presentation, this will also lessen the inflammatory response mediated by T helper cells.

3.4 Inhibitors of mast cells

First used to treat asthma in 1968, sodium chloroglicate (SCG) is the quintessential mast-cell-stabilizing medication. In 1984, nedocromil sodium was added to the list of medications. Following inhalation, both medications block the early- and late-phase reactions brought on by allergens in the conjunctiva, upper and lower airways, and mucosal mast cells, which play a critical role in the allergic response (Edwards and Howell 2000). Nedocromil sodium and SCG raise the threshold for activation99 by preventing the flow of chloride ions in mast cells, epithelial cells, neurons. A Ca2+-activated K+ channel, K(Ca)3.1, is also expressed by human mast cells and promotes mast-cell chemotaxis and increases IgE-dependent mast-cell activation. This suggests that blocking K(Ca)3.1 with medications like clotrimazole and TRAM-34 (1-[(2-chlorophenyl) diphenylmethyl]-1H-pyrazole) may be a novel method of inhibiting mast cells (Edwards and Howell 2000).

The tetraspanin protein family member CD63 is another recently discovered cell-surface target on mast cells. CD63 alters adhesion to fibronectin and vitronectin by interacting with the α3, α4, and α6 chains of β1 integrins and interfering with integrin signaling, localization, or trafficking. A monoclonal antibody that suppresses CD63 prevents extracellular matrix protein-adherent mast cells from being activated by FcεRI, but not nonadherent cells (Kraft, Fleming et al. 2005). The biochemical events that are started by the binding of FcεRI103 are significantly modulated by the SRC tyrosine kinases FYN and LYN. Inactivating the SYK that promotes FcεRI signaling104 is a unique method of preventing mast-cell activation. A reversible mast-cell SYK inhibitor105 was identified as 2,4-diaminopyrimidine (R112) via a cell-based, high-throughput screen for small compounds that block IgE signaling. In allergic rhinitis, intranasal R112 treatment followed by allergen exposure prevented rhinorrhea and nasal blockage in addition to inhibiting the formation of prostaglandin D2 (Meltzer, Berkowitz et al. 2005).

For mast cell growth, proliferation, survival, homing, and adhesion, as well as for the best possible IgE-induced mast-cell degranulation and cytokine release, stem-cell factor (SCF) must interact with its tyrosine-kinase receptor KIT. SCF-specific antibodies, antisense oligonucleotides, KIT inhibitors, and inhibitors of downstream signaling pathways are examples of potential medications that target SCF or KIT.

3.5 Cytokine-based immunotherapies

TH2 cytokines and their receptors are important therapeutic targets due to their sentinel function in coordinating allergic inflammation (Figure.5). This strategy has nearly always involved the use of biological agents, such as fusion proteins, blocking monoclonal antibodies, and, most recently, inhibitors of the TH2-cell transcription factors GATA3 and STAT6 (signal transducer and activator of transcription 6).

IL-4 In order for B cells to manufacture IgE, they must switch their immunoglobulin isotype, and IL-4 by itself is essential for preserving the TH2-cell phenotype. For these reasons, both cytokines are promising targets for therapy. Many investigations on animals have demonstrated that preventing the generation of IL-4 or reducing its effects has a significant impact on the allergy phenotype. It is a non-immunogenic soluble, recombinant human IL-4 receptor (altrakincept) made up of the extracellular part of human IL-4Rα. Nebulized inhalation altrakincept was shown to be effective in a 12-week proof of concept trial in patients with mild to moderate asthma by permitting cessation of inhaled corticosteroid medication without recurrence. This finding was then verified in a larger trial (Borish, Nelson et al. 2001).

However, the effectiveness of altrakincept in treating asthma was not confirmed by a Phase III trial. Although there were issues with the bioavailability of altrakincept in this investigation, this trial does not rule out IL-4 as a target for the treatment of allergies and asthma. Additional Phase II humanized IL-4-specific and IL-4Rα-blocking antibodies, as pascolizumab (SB240,683)120, are being used in ongoing research. Two IL-4 vaccines have been tested in mice: one involves chemically coupling IL-4 to limpet haemocyanin121, and the other involves inserting a 14-amino acid peptide from IL-4 into the core antigen of the varian hepatitis B virus. (Linhart, Bigenzahn et al. 2007)Both vaccinations prevented lung inflammation brought on by antigens and produced significant antibody titres specific for mouse IL-4. However, it was discovered that the secondary IgE response is not T-cell dependent when co-stimulation blocking was used in a rat model of grass pollen allergy. This raises questions about the efficacy of IL-4 blockade in treating established allergic illness.

IL-13. IL-13 is an important therapeutic target in allergy and asthma because of its many roles in controlling IgE production, eosinophilic inflammation, airway smooth-muscle hyperplasia, inducing goblet-cell hyperplasia with mucus production, and attracting monocytes, macrophages, and T cells into the airway spaces124. Both a low-affinity IL‑13Rα1 subunit and a high-affinity complex made up of IL‑ and IL‑4Rα are bound by IL‑13. When this high-affinity complex is bound, Janus kinase 1 (JAK1), JAK2, and STAT6 are activated phosphorylation-dependently. Additionally, IL-4Rα enhances IL-13-mediated responses by stabilizing IL-13's binding to its receptor. Nevertheless, the action of IL-13 is strongly inhibited by IL-13Rα2, a non-signalling, high-affinity IL-13-binding chain. A soluble version of IL-13Rα2, which competes for binding to IL-13 but not to IL-4, has been used to selectively inhibit IL-13 in mice. This has caused the formation of mucus and a reversal of airway hyperresponsiveness in mice that have been sensitized to allergens. Serum from mice but not from humans has a soluble version of IL-13Rα2, which binds IL-13 with an affinity 100 times higher than that of IL-13Rα1 (Andrews, Nasir et al. 2006).

IL-5. Numerous models of asthma have shown that IL-5 plays a significant role, according to research on rodents and nonhuman primates. For people with asthma, inhaled IL-5 reduces the quantity of eosinophil progenitors in their airways and bone marrow, but for people without asthma, it causes localized eosinophilia. To treat asthma, two humanized, human IL-5-specific monoclonal antibodies have been created: mepolizumab (SB-240,563) and Sch-55,700. Surprisingly, mepolizumab had no effect on the late asthmatic response or airway hyperresponsiveness despite producing a rapid dose-dependent drop in circulating and sputum eosinophil counts that lasted for three months in a small, double-blind experiment (Leckie, ten Brinke et al. 2000). Sch-55,700 treatment reduced blood eosinophil counts in a group of patients with severe persistent asthma, but it had no effect on any asthma outcome measures over a 10-week period134. This finding was recently supported by a sizable trial using mepolizumab.

IL-9. In animal models, IL-9 blockade decreases allergen-induced airway inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness. An IL-9-specific monoclonal antibody has undergone two successful Phase I dose-escalation trials in healthy volunteers. There are currently phase II trials underway to treat persistent, moderate-to-severe asthma symptoms (O'Byrne, Boulet et al. 2007).

IL-12. A potent signal from IL-12 directs naive precursor T cells to differentiate into TH1 cells both in vitro and in vivo, changing the immune response to cell-mediated immunity. In animal models, IL-12 administered during sensitization decreases airway hyperresponsiveness and airway eosinophilia following antigen challenge, as well as allergen-induced TH2-cell responses in favor of TH1-cell growth. Whole blood cell synthesis of IL-12 and airway biopsies expression of it are both compromised in asthma. Thus, IL-12 has the capacity to alter allergy conditions. Patients with mild asthma who received injections of recombinant human IL-12 experienced flu-like symptoms, abnormal liver-function tests, and cardiac arrhythmias in addition to a decrease in circulating blood eosinophils following allergen challenge (but not sputum eosinophilia, the late-phase response, or airway hyperresponsiveness) (Kuipers, Heirman et al. 2004). The finding that DCs retrovirally overexpressing IL-12 in mice produce robust TH1-cell responses to inhaled antigen in the lung but are unable to inhibit TH2-cell polarization following sensitization calls into question this strategy as well.

IL-10. IL-10 is the primary inhibitory cytokine generated by TReg cells in allergen immunotherapy, and it suppresses the expression of numerous proinflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and pro-inflammatory enzymes. After allergen challenge, IL-10-deficient animals exhibit elevated airway inflammation; in outbred mice, this was prevented by intratracheal delivery of the IL-10 gene. IL-10 administration to healthy individuals reduces the quantity of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in circulation while suppressing endotoxin-driven TNF and IL-1β production and mitogen-induced T-cell proliferation (Fu, Chuang et al. 2006).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Figure.5. Cytokine-based therapies in asthma. Since allergic inflammation is primarily a T helper 2 (TH2)-cell disease, there has been a strong push to change the TH2-–TH1-cell balance in asthma. This has been accomplished either by enhancing TH1-cell responses (interferon-γ (IFNγ) and IL-12) or by blocking TH2-cell cytokines (particularly interleukin-4 (IL-4), IL-13, and IL-5). IgE-specific monoclonal antibodies can also be used to inhibit the allergic component of atopic asthma. TCR stands for T-cell receptor; rh stands for recombinant human; FceRI for high-affinity receptor for IgE; and APC for antigen-presenting cell.

 

 

 

 

Conclusions

Asthma and other allergy illnesses have become much more common in recent decades, impacting an estimated 20% of the population in affluent nations. Recent discoveries about the pathophysiology of allergies and asthma as well as the molecular mechanism behind the activation of important target cells present therapeutic opportunities. In addition to being useful in treating asthma, anti-IgE therapy may also be useful in treating other allergic conditions like rhinitis and food allergies. There are currently compounds in clinical development that block mast cell activation at the receptor or intracellular level, and methods to counteract pro-inflammatory mediators like TNF-α have showed promise in treating individuals with severe asthma. Allergen-specific immunotherapy (SIT ) to produce blocking IgG4 antibodies and immunological tolerance.

metadata.title: The role of the transcription factor NF-kB in the pathogenesis of inflammation and carcinogenesis. Modulation capabilities
metadata.description: The nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kB) signaling module is a complex and highly interconnected molecular network with important functions in all nucleated cells. Most chronic diseases caused by lifestyle factors appear to be related to inflammation. The NF-kB plays a major role in the pathogenesis of the inflammation and its intimate molecular mechanism. This transcription factor participates in the evolution of diabetes and its complications. In T1D (Type 1 Diabetes), proinflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-1β (IL-1β), tumor necrosis factor (TNF), and CD40L secreted by immune cells in islets induce the activation of NF-kB in β-cells through both canonical and noncanonical roads. NF-kB activation increases the expression of genes, including TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, MCP-1, and ICAM-1, that initiate and promote atherosclerosis. In particular, the severity and lethality of acute lung injury or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ALI/ARDS) caused by pneumonia or sepsis is primarily associated with an NF-kB-mediated "cytokine storm," in which massive polymorphonuclear (PMN) extravasation and the subsequent release of cytokines cause rapid deterioration due to widespread inflammation and coagulation. Nuclear translocation of NF-kB p65 can induce the transcription of several genes involved in the induction of EMT (epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition). This has been confirmed in various types of cancer, including brain, breast, lung, and gastric cancer. Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) encompasses a group of lymphoproliferative disorders characterized by invasive neoplastic T cells in the skin and various clinical prognoses. In the early stages of CTCL, NF-kB activation and cell proliferation are stimulated by the autocrine production of TNFα, leading to increased NF-kB activation and resistance to apoptosis. Bladder cancer is the second most common genitourinary cancer and is often recurrent and/or chemoresistant after tumor resection. NF-kB is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in normal physiology and bladder cancer. Bladder cancer patients have pathologically active NF-kB induced by proinflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and hypoxia, enhancing carcinogenesis and progression of the disease.

metadata.title: The role of palmitoylation of the insulin receptor in insulin resistance: A hypothesis
metadata.description: Palmitoylation is attachment of a palmitoyl group to the cysteine residues of a protein. The intermediary in this process is Palmitoyl CoA, which is formed during the activation of fatty acids in the beta oxidationn of the palmitic acid, consequent to the shift of the energy metabolism to beta oxidation from glycolysis, in DM2.The insulin receptor has cysteine rich domains in the cytosolic portion of the beta sub unit connected by disulfide bonds. It is hypothesized that the palmitoylation forms a thio-ester bond with cystein residues of the beta sub units of the insulin receptor. Depalmitoylation results in substitution of thiol (-SH) in place of the disulfide (S-S) bonds (S-S), due to the hydrolysis by the thio-esterase enzyme. The disulfide bonds are responsible for formation of the functional tettameric form of the insulin receptor. Consequent to the substitution of the SH group in place of S-S group, during depalmitoylation, the functional specificity of the insulin receptor is lost. This leads to the failure of conformational changes and auto- phoshorylation of the beta sub units when insulin binds to the extra cellular insulin binding receptor domain. Also failure of the cascade of phosphorylation of other signalling proteins occurs. Consequently, the failure of the intra- cellular transduction of the signals results in failure of the translocation of the GLUT 4 transporter to the cell membrane. This results in the hyperglycaemia in spite of hyper insulinemia and mo glucose enters into the cell- a state called insulin resistance in DM 2.

metadata.title: Data set related to the article: "Klebsiella pneumoniae-OMVs activate death-signaling pathways in Human Bronchial Epithelial Host Cells (BEAS-2B)"
metadata.description:
The programmed cell death pathways of apoptosis are important in mammalian cellular protection
from infections. The activation of these pathways depends on the presence of membrane
receptors that bind bacterial components to activate the transduction mechanism. In addition to
bacteria, these mechanisms can be activated by outer membrane vesicles (OMVs). OMVs are
spherical vesicles of 20–250 nm diameter, constitutively released by Gram-negative bacteria.
They contain several bacterial determinants including proteins, DNA/RNA and proteins, that
activate different cellular processes in host cells. This study focused on Klebsiella pneumoniae-
OMVs in activating death mechanisms in human bronchial epithelial cells (BEAS-2B). Characterization
of purified OMVs was achieved by scanning electron microscopy, nanoparticle tracking
analysis and protein profiling. Cell viability was assessed by the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-
diphenyltetrazolium bromide assay while apoptotic induction was measured by flow cytometry
and confirmed by western blotting. The OMVs produced showed a spherical morphology, with a
diameter of 137.2 ± 41 nm and a vesicular density of 7.8 × 109 particles/mL Exposure of cell
monolayers to 50 μg of K. pneumoniae-OMV for 14 h resulted in approximately 25 % cytotoxicity
and 41.15–41.14 % of cells undergoing early and late apoptosis. Fluorescence microscopy
revealed reduced cellular density, the presence of apoptotic bodies, chromatin condensation, and
nuclear membrane blebbing in residual cells. Activation of caspases 􀀀 3 and 􀀀 9 and dysregulation
of BAX, BIM and Bcl-xL indicated the activation of mitochondria-dependent apoptosis. Furthermore,
a decrease in the antioxidant enzymes superoxide dismutase, catalase and glutathione
peroxidase involved endoplasmic reticulum stress with the potential formation of reactive oxygen species.

These findings provide evidence for the role of OMVs in apoptosis and involvement in the
pathogenesis of K. pneumoniae infections.
